reviewText: There's a lot to say for, "Home Run" particularly the powerful message of God's healing and forgiveness, as the film deals with the issue of alcoholism in an honest way and highlights the work of the ministry Celebrate Recovery. Some of the baseball scenes ae decently handled and star Scott Elrod turns in a solid performanceThat said, the film does have problems. At nearly two hours, the film at least half an hour too long with padding and a plot that seemed to ramble. The baseball parts often didn't make sense as the movie's understanding of how things like all-star team voting, suspensions (and appeals), as well as releasing a player didn't seem to work. Indeed these elements were used to force the plot along. At the same time, it felt like other things were happening that we weren't seeing on screen that may have made the story make more sense. This is backed up by the fact that the movie novelization is more than 400 pages long. The producers didn't do a job of narrowing this down to a good cinematic story.The film had a good message, but if it doesn't use its medium well that makes it harder for the message to get out.
summary: A Movie That Doesn't Reach The Fences

reviewText: I really liked this faith-based movie.  It covered some tough subjects (family abuse, alcoholism) and wasn't afraid to give the glory to God.  The cast of characters were believable and likable.  Anyone who has battled a stronghold in their life would probably tell you that they couldn't do it on their own.  This was the baseline for the story.  Cory, the main character, realizing that he couldn't stop drinking was the beginning of his recovery.  God gave him the strength to do what he couldn't do on his own, but I loved at the end how when he drives by the bar he slows his truck and you see him shake his head.  He still battles the temptation to do it.  It didn't completely go away, but God gives him the strength to keep on going and not turn into that old temptation.  This was a great movie with an even better message.  I totally recommend it.

reviewText: This film is good.  Good acting  by the leads, better than average production values and a compelling story just a bit bogged down by predictability.  Most stories like this are told because they are success stories. We watch and through empathy and a need to see ourselves in the lead, experience the personality arc of an individual whose life is pained by unfinished business and painful experiences as a young person. This film brings us through the period when the lead comes close and ultimately hits the wall. For me, the only failure of the film was not blending the Christian values style of therapy with the leads need for recovery, as well as it may have. Considering the ending and closing screen shots.All in all though a good film well worth the time and energy. I enjoyed it. I will also recommend it to others.

reviewText: I am amazed at the amount of  people who rated this a "christian propaganda film" because god was mentioned in his AA meetings which is a well known christian based program. It appeared to me to be someone who may have really found assistance in the AA program.Things I did not like about the movie:SPOILERS1.  The movie is very slow.  A little on the boring side2.  Part of the story is very contrived.  Famous ex boyfriend comes back to small town...problems arise, flirting and resistance from the ex girlfriend.3.  The reaction from the son seemed fake and forced.4. Things didn't seem to resolve between the brothers.Things I did like:1.  I thought for sure this was going to be about re-kindling an old romance/instantly re-igniting a family once forgotten...It was nice it didn't SEEM like they just started right where they left out and he had an insta-family.2.  The acting was not too shabby3.  The lead actor was smokin hot.Overall I wouldn't watch it again, but not upset that I did watch it. If I new the ending now, wouldn't watch it so I would give it 2.75 stars.

reviewText: HOME RUN is a well written powerful story about a baseball player named Cory Brand who had many challenges as a young boy growing up with a difficult father. He took those feelings of abandonment and disappointment into his adult life which led him to make choices which were not the best for him or his career.Meeting the right people while coaching a little league baseball team in his home town helped him to learn to forgive, trust in God, and acknowledge his abuse of alcohol. He was able to then move on in his life which brought him love, acceptance, redemption, and hope.It is a family movie but I am not sure young children will understand the major theme. I think watching it with older children, middle school and high school children could lead to a family discussion about the theme of the movie and the choices we make and consequences they have in our lives.I feel it is a movie worth watching. It definitely has application to our lives today.*I received a copy for review - all opinions are my own*

reviewText: I think it's fair to acknowledge up front that this is a Christian movie and that if you're someone who's ardently anti-Christian you probably won't like this movie. And parents should be warned that there is at times some fairly frank discussion of sexual addiction and some intense anger/violence (not graphic violence, but the intensity of the actors could make it scary for young kids).The movie does have a great message about the healing power of God's love and the way it can fulfill you where earthly pleasures cannot, and that this is the major problem with the emptiness that so many would say they feel in their lives. The plot is mostly about abuse and addiction and why it occurs (addiction not just to alcohol and drugs). Most of the movie is spent with the main character unwilling to admit that he has a problem with alcohol but it does portray a number of other individuals (through the context of his 12-step program) who have recognized they have a problem and that becoming a born-again Christian has been a major step in their recovery. Is the movie a bit simplistic in seeming to imply that this single step alone is sufficient and that these individuals won't fall back on their old ways? Sure, although there is a hint at the very end that Cory will struggle from time to time (when he comes back  to Okmulgee at the very end, he drives very slowly past the bar).The plot is well done and the actors did a great job of portraying the characters. Much like "Courageous", there are few flaws in the script or plot, a rarity in indie-developed Christian movies. Scott Elrod portrays Cory as a likable person but with serious issues. He does a terrific job with Cory's addiction, the roots of his issues, his anger, and eventual transformation. When he finally breaks and admits he has a problem, you really feel it. If I had to pick one issue, it is that the movie speeds too quickly past his transformation and acceptance of Christ after his admission of his addiction where it might have spent some time on it.Too bad Hollywood can't do more movies like this.

reviewText: I just finished watching Home Run, i had pre-purchased it on a whim (ive been trying to stir up my christian spirit after years of neglect).  What a wonderful, inspiring, totally non-preachy, blessing of a film this is!!!  To many of us who are between living a worldly and a christian life, this movie will talk to your heart and help put a personal touch to the experiences that we face day to day.  On so many levels we can relate to this movie, sports, real life, being down and out, and deciding whether or not we want to stay in a rut/die, or find peace and true happiness.  This movie plays out to the very end to reach the conclusion that we all must make if we are to truly "find the way" to a happier, healthier, purposeful, life.  And trust me, im no preacher!!!  This movie doesnt preach, it just shows it in love : )

reviewText: This is a Christian propaganda film masquerading as a Little League coaching film. In reality it is a substance-abuse picture, covering various dysfunctional scenarios and in this respect is reasonably well-written. Alcoholic semi-pro's life falls apart and so must coach a kid's team, while going through recovery. This is a drama and not a comedy and is an adult rather than a kid's film; and I would say is not for kids.  It's not a particularly 'feel good' flic! Reasonably acted and written and might be of interest to someone who has had to deal with any type of substance abuse or dysfunctionalism in their life, if you can ignore the propaganda!

reviewText: I hate to ruin the story but it really looks enticing if you like baseball...  The problem is, the movie focuses very little around baseball, other than the fact that a baseball player is an alcoholic and he needs "Jesus" to get his life straightened out.  My 8 year old son was initially excited about the start of the movie as it appeared it was going to be an awesome baseball movie.  By half-time he was snoring...asleep...and so was I.  I got the same message at a friends church a few weeks ago..when the minister wanted to "save" me.  If you need to be "saved", this is a good movie to watch, but don't watch it thinking it has anything to do with baseball.  At least I am saved now.

reviewText: I watched this after seeing the previews, and I'm so glad I did. It's technically a Christian movie, which is great because that meant it would be clean, but the religious aspect wasn't overwhelming. This movie is really a heart-warming and uplifting story with a touching message and characters who draw you into their emotions. Scott Elrod (aside from being nice to look at) did a great job in this movie. The young boy (don't recall his name right now) was another favorite character. Overall, this is a great family show that I would highly recommend. The acting isn't top-notch, but that didn't matter--everything else about the story and characters made up for it. There is an adult-themed message with the alcoholism, but it's well done, and I'd have no problem sharing this with older children. I know I'll watch this again.

reviewText: First of all this review isn't about this movie, it's about what movies should be.Gore, blood and guts NoneSex scenes NoneFoul language NoneAwesome GCI effects NoneOscar winning performances by the cast NoneUnbelieve stunts NoneHow on earth can you make a movie that the public will watch without any of the above?Maybe because more and more of the Faith/Christian based movies are making it into theaters today more and more people are  getting to see and enjoy them. The first two movies in this catergory that I got to watch were Courageous and October Baby and they got me hooked.The majority of these movies simply tell a story(without the help of the previously listed items)without being preachy. These movies don't make a ton of money at the box office but it didn't cost a ton of money to make them, these movies sell well when released to dvd they will normally cost $14.95 and less as opposed to $19.95 and up for the other releases, these movies are normally available at Redbox and Netflix. They are true family movies, which can be enjoyed by all.If you are not watching these movies you have no idea what your missing and to the studios turning out these movies keep up the good work.I am trying to find a movie entitled "Endings" its a couple years old and I don't think it ever played in theaters nationally, it looks like an interesting story.

reviewText: Having been invited to watch this movie in it's first week at the local movie theater by the mom of one of the production crew, I was mostly accepting her invitation, to be a supportive friend & have some popcorn! A baseball movie doesn't sound very interesting! Even my teenage son declined to come, saying:  "You lost me at 'Baseball'"But I was taken into another world, starting with the FIRST scene: a painful flashback to a childhood trauma, then brought up to speed with the main character's life. At that point I was emotionally invested and completely engaged. Poignant soundtrack: I bought two songs for my itunes playlist. Deals head-on with some very tough subjects, and follows through on some realistic, genuine, and touching outcomes. "Life isn't perfect, but you need to step up to the plate and give it your best try." I want to get a copy of this movie and see it again!

reviewText: Loved it!! Feel good movie that shows how the weaknesses and disappointment of a parent manifests itself on the innocent children and then the burdens and demons they in turn have to bear. Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie focuses primarily on the life of a person who endured an abusive childhood and coped with it through alcohol.  It presents the consequences of allowing such a course to take control of a person's life and those that are close to them.  Additionally, it presents a twelve-step recovery program, "Celebrate Recovery", which is Christian based; along with testimonials of people who went through diverse life challenges and how God changed their life.  Although their lives are not perfect now, their lives are better-off because of God in their life.Although the main character of the film does present his testimony at the end of the film, the film does not present his conversion experience (e.g. sinner's prayer, or praying with the CR leader on the scene where he confessed to the leader that he could not stop drinking and stop the cycle).  As time passes by, more faith-based films are doing this, and to me, this is falling short of scripture:... "if you confess with your mouth the Lord Jesus and believe in your heart that God has raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.  For with the heart one believes unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation." (Rom. 10:9-10).If it were not for this, I would give the film five stars.  Nonetheless, I would highly recommend this movie for people who are struggling with addictions of any kind and for people who work with or live around them as well. Check-it out for yourself!

reviewText: "Nothing great happens when you hold back." Cory Brand (Elrod) is the best baseball player in the country. He has a huge following and is the heart and soul of his team. He also has a very quick and violent temper. After throwing a tantrum during a game he is suspended and sent back to his hometown for rehab. While there in order to keep his image clean he is also to coach the local little league team. Little by little the rehab, coaching and a higher power start to change his life. I am a huge fan of sports movies so this is one I sat down expecting to like. I did not realize going in that it was also a religious themed film. I do not automatically discount a movie because of that aspect because I have seen some that are very good, but this one like so many others like it are just too unbelievable. I have no problem with putting prayer in a movie or showing religious beliefs but when simply saying I now believe in God instantly makes life better and fixes everything it really takes away from the rest of the movie and makes it feel like a commercial for religion. It may be because I was raised Catholic and therefore cynical but to make a religious movie believable would mean that prayer helps but isn't an automatic fix all. Sorry for that tirade. Overall, a good movie that is worth watching but the religious aspect took me out of the movie. I give it a B-.
summary: A movie that is well worth watching but the "god fixes everything" aspect really made it unbelievable for me. I say B-.
